title: [Onprem] Align Python Versions
body:
After some discussion, the conclusion from last week to align user and admin's python (for submitting Ray jobs, since the Ray cluster is launched via admin's python) is to add an `admin_python` field to the cluster config, indicating the path of admin's python binary.

```
cluster:
  ips:
  - 20.232.111.246
  name: azure-onprem

auth:
  ssh_user: test
  ssh_private_key: ~/.ssh/sky-key

admin_python: /usr/bin/python3
```

body:

title: Canonicalize accelerator names in Resources
body:
Fixes #995.

To prevent potential bugs due to lower-case names, I think we should canonicalize the accelerator names in `Resources`. Because there are only < 20 accelerators (except TPUs) in three clouds, we can maintain a hard-coded list of accelerator names. Using them, we can avoid reading the whole catalogs in most cases.

Note that this list (`_ACCELERATORS`) must also include accelerators supported for local clusters.

Tested:
* `sky exec --gpus v100`, `sky exec --gpus V100`
* `sky exec --gpus a10g`, `sky exec --gpus A10g`, `sky exec --gpus A10G`

title: Fix GCP catalog bugs due to website typos
body:
![Screen Shot 2022-08-13 at 6 32 58 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46394894/184518872-1e4afb72-1591-4b57-b4c1-1a271914e3f2.png)

I found two typos in the GCP website that affect our catalog.
1. In `us-central1-b`, a comma is omitted between T2A and N1.
2. In `us-central1-c`, a space is omitted between C2 and C2D.

This PR fixes the gcp catalog crawler to handle these typos. However, the 4 instances (T2A and N1 on us-central1-b, and C2 and C2D on us-central1-c) will not be available until the next catalog update.

title: For CLI-like messages, use print() not logging.
body:
The programmatic API PR changed some prior logging messages from just print() to logger.info() in core.py. This PR reverts those changes for the old behavior, which is arguably a more CLI-like experience.

Before this PR (note the `core.py` prefixed messages):
```
» sky queue c2
Fetching and parsing job queue...
I 08-10 19:11:14 core.py:264]
I 08-10 19:11:14 core.py:264] Sky Job Queue of Cluster c2
ID  NAME     SUBMITTED    STARTED      DURATION     RESOURCES     STATUS     LOG
20  sky-cmd  1 hr ago     1 hr ago     < 1s         1x [CPU:1]    SUCCEEDED  ~/sky_logs/sky-2022-08-10-17-16-20-247074

» sky cancel c2 -a
I 08-10 19:11:29 core.py:303] Cancelling all jobs on cluster 'c2'...

» sky logs c2 20
I 08-10 19:11:50 core.py:334] Tailing logs of job 20 on cluster 'c2'...
I 08-11 02:11:51 log_lib.py:373] Start streaming logs for job 20.
...

» sky logs c2 20 --status
I 08-10 19:11:41 core.py:389] Getting job status...
Job 20: SUCCEEDED
```

Now:
```
» sky queue c2
Fetching and parsing job queue...

Job queue of cluster c2
ID  NAME     SUBMITTED    STARTED      DURATION     RESOURCES     STATUS     LOG
20  sky-cmd  1 hr ago     1 hr ago     < 1s         1x [CPU:1]    SUCCEEDED  ~/sky_logs/sky-2022-08-10-17-16-20-247074

» sky cancel c2 -a
Cancelling all jobs on cluster 'c2'...

» sky logs c2
Tailing logs of the last job on cluster 'c2'...
I 08-10 19:10:03 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2210] Job ID not provided. Streaming the logs of the latest job.
...

» sky logs c2 20 --status
Getting job status...
Job 20: SUCCEEDED
```

title: Change default scheduling demand of 0.5 cpu/task to 1.
body:
Fixes #1045 - see that issue for the motivation of the change (UX/confusion on user's front).

**This change will half the maximum number of concurrent tasks**, compared to master. This means 
- for p3.2x (V100 x1), from 16 jobs to 8 jobs.  Should be fine as we're not seeing 1 GPU being shared among 8 jobs.
- similar argument for say, `(n1-highmem-8, tpu-v3-8:1)`.

Tested: exec'ing before and after:
```
» sky queue c2
Fetching and parsing job queue...
I 08-10 17:16:34 core.py:264]
I 08-10 17:16:34 core.py:264] Sky Job Queue of Cluster c2
ID  NAME     SUBMITTED    STARTED         DURATION     RESOURCES     STATUS     LOG
20  -        11 secs ago  a few secs ago  < 1s         1x [CPU:1]    SUCCEEDED  ~/sky_logs/sky-2022-08-10-17-16-20-247074
19  -        44 mins ago  44 mins ago     < 1s         1x [CPU:0.5]  SUCCEEDED  ~/sky_logs/sky-2022-08-10-16-32-09-948710
```

title: UX: type check sky.exec()'s first argument, and hint.
body:
Fixes #982, encountered by Erick a while ago.


Before
```
> sky.exec('echo hi', cluster_name=name)
...
    assert len(dag) == 1, f’Sky assumes 1 task for now. {dag}'
AssertionError: Sky assumes 1 task for now. echo hi
```

Now hinting with a copy-pasteable snippet:
```
> sky.exec('echo hi', cluster_name=name)
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
    raise TypeError(_EXEC_STRING_AS_DAG_HINT_MESSAGE)
TypeError: Programmatic API sky.exec() expects a sky.Dag but received a string.

If you meant to run a command, make it a Task's run command and wrap as a Dag:

  def to_dag(command, gpu=None):
      with sky.Dag() as dag:
          sky.Task(run=command).set_resources(
              sky.Resources(accelerators=gpu))
      return dag

  sky.exec(to_dag(cmd), cluster_name=..., ...)

If the task needs accelerators:

  sky.exec(to_dag(cmd, gpu='V100'), cluster_name=..., ...)
  sky.exec(to_dag(cmd, gpu={'V100': 1}), cluster_name=..., ...)
  sky.exec(to_dag(cmd, gpu='V100:0.5'), cluster_name=..., ...)```
```
Note that this check/hint would only be triggered by using the programmatic API, not by the CLI.

title: Install aws by default
body:
Based on the offline discussion, we found it makes sense to install AWS CLI by default when installing skypilot:
1. The AWS most commonly used by our users.
2. It makes no sense to install a no-cloud version of skypilot with `pip install skypilot`
3. The installation of AWS CLI is pretty quick.

This also fixes the hint in the document for installing `grpc` for Apple Silicon.

I will cherry-pick this PR into the `releases/0.1.1`.

title: Surface setup error
body:
Closes #518.

It surfaces the setup error at the end of the error message, as proposed by @concretevitamin.

Tested yaml:
```
setup: |
  set -ex
  somenonexit command
  echo "running setup"
```

Previously,
```
sky.exceptions.CommandError: Command /bin/bash -i /tmp/sky_setup_jsyb5vgm 2>&1 failed with return code 127.
Failed to setup with return code 127.
```

Currently,
```
sky.exceptions.CommandError: Command /bin/bash -i /tmp/sky_setup_jsyb5vgm 2>&1 failed with return code 127.
Failed to setup with return code 127. Check the details in log: ~/sky_logs/sky-2022-08-07-00-19-04-685768/setup-34.227.105.10.log.

****** START Last lines of setup output ******
+ somenonexit command
+ '[' -x /usr/lib/command-not-found ']'
+ /usr/lib/command-not-found -- somenonexit
somenonexit: command not found

******* END Last lines of setup output *******
```

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c fail-setup ./run.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c fail-setup-2 --num-nodes 2 ./run.yaml`

title: Make multiple threads creating their own sky.Dag() thread-safe.
body:
Thanks to the report by @Michaelvll, who saw that test_multiecho is failing:
```
[?25hTraceback (most recent call last):
  File "examples/multi_echo.py", line 45, in <module>
    run(cluster)
  File "examples/multi_echo.py", line 37, in run
    list(p.imap(_exec, range(32)))
  File "/Users/zhwu/miniconda3/envs/sky-dev/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 868, in next
    raise value
  File "/Users/zhwu/miniconda3/envs/sky-dev/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 125, in worker
    result = (True, func(*args, **kwds))
  File "examples/multi_echo.py", line 34, in _exec
    sky.exec(dag, cluster_name=cluster, detach_run=True)
  File "/Users/zhwu/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiment-dev/sky/utils/common_utils.py", line 129, in _record
    return f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/zhwu/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiment-dev/sky/execution.py", line 249, in exec
    _execute(dag=dag,
  File "/Users/zhwu/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/AResource/PhD/Research/sky-computing/code/sky-experiment-dev/sky/execution.py", line 93, in _execute
    assert len(dag) == 1, f'We support 1 task for now. {dag}'
AssertionError: We support 1 task for now. DAG:
[]

Reading the code, 

https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/a04d14922de8dfd0ec5351b64a65eb61c6290b36/examples/multi_echo.py#L23-L33

this is likely because `sky.Dag() -> DagContext` wasn't thread-safe. This PR makes it so.

title: Fix job status transition
body:
Thanks to the observation by @michaelzhiluo (https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/969#issuecomment-1203440396), we found that there is a bug in mismatching of `job_lib.query_job_status` and `job_lib.get_status`.
Previously, we map the ray job status to sky job status with
```
'PENDING': JobStatus.PENDING
'RUNNING': JobStatus.RUNNING
```
This will cause a problem for the job status transition. When a job has not been allocated with required resources, the job will be set to RUNNING in the skylet, due to the following line.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/2cb62c542cfc48761d710586bb926f661722ac94/sky/skylet/job_lib.py#L278

**This PR also fixes the race condition caused by periodic job status update by skylet and job status set in generated ray program.**

Tested:
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: [Onprem] Align Python versions between user and admin
body:
A common issue that @romilbhardwaj  and @Michaelvll faced was setting up new users for the local cluster and aligning the Ray cluster's python version and the user's python version. After deeper investigation, it is due to conda's base environment (or in Azure's case, `py38_base_env`), which can potentially have a diff python version. 

This PR aims to make user's python and root user's python point to the same binary. This is done by forcefully deactivating the conda "base" environment in the Jinja file, which defaults the python back to the system's python instead of anaconda.

title: Add zone support in YAML
body:
This PR adds support for specifying zone in YAML which avoids the need to modify catalog manually. This feature can be useful for TPU users who often get quota only in specific zones (such as `us-central1-c` but not `us-central1-a`).
Also, some accelerator validation is added when region/zone is specified.
I'm not sure whether CLI argument overwrite (`--zone`) is useful so I remove it in the latest commit. But we can bring it back if needed.

Usage example:
```
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  zone: europe-west4-a
  accelerators: tpu-v3-8
  accelerator_args:
    runtime_version: tpu-vm-base
    tpu_vm: True
```

Hint example:
```
(sky) weichiang@mbp sky % sky launch examples/tpu/tpuvm_mnist.yaml
Task from YAML spec: examples/tpu/tpuvm_mnist.yaml
ValueError: Accelerator "tpu-v2-8" is not available in "us-central1-a" region/zone.
```

title: New project name: SkyPilot
body:
The core development team has voted to change the project name to **SkyPilot**. Going forward, this will be the name we use to refer to the project.

**What this affects**
- all branding materials (docs, README, talks, etc.)
- (in the near future) GitHub org & repo name
- (in the near future) `pip install skypilot` to install the package

**What is NOT changed**
- the handy CLI `sky` name (namely, users still use `sky launch/exec/status/...`)
- the handy python `sky` name (namely, Python users still do `import sky` or `sky.launch(...)`, etc.)

**What do I have to do as a user/dev if I have previously installed `sky`?**
- You may need to rerun `pip install -e .` to install the new package `skypilot`
- You usage patterns should not need any changes, as mentioned above
- (For devs) Change [`SKY_*` env vars](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky#environment-variable-options) to `SKYPILOT_*`

**Approach taken in this PR**
- I've renamed the project in README & Docs, which are the most important outward facing branding materials
- I've changed certain -- but not all -- source files to reflect the new name
  - Reasoning: 
     - we can lazily change the rest of the files on edit (e.g., if a new PR touches lines/files that use the old 'Sky' branding, change them); 
     - moreover, they may require backward compatibility testing, including but not limited to the ones outlined below

-----

**Overall tests**
- [X] `sky launch -y examples/minimal.yaml` prints everything normally
- [X] smoke -- all passed except test_spot_storage
- [ ] back-compat tests
  - old cluster, UP: can be reused
    - [ ] can sky exec --- Bug: due to changing start_streaming_at, no output
      - this is because it has old log_lib, which checks for 'SKY INFO:'
    - [X] can sky launch
    - [X] can sky stop + sky start + sky exec
    - [X] can `sky autostop` + `sky status -r`
  - old cluster, STOPPED: can be reused
    - [X] can sky launch + sky exec + sky queue + sky logs
      - [X] 1 node
      - [X] 2 nodes
    - [X] can sky start + sky exec + sky queue + sky logs
    - [X] check in cloud console that there's no leaked VM 

Back compat tests: old cluster, UP: can be reused
```bash
# FIXME, not OK: can sky exec
git checkout master
sky launch -c commit-4240 examples/minimal.yaml
git checkout project-name
# FIXME: no output
sky exec commit-4240 examples/minimal.yaml

# OK: can sky launch
git checkout master
sky launch -c commit-4240-1 examples/minimal.yaml
git checkout project-name
sky launch -c commit-4240-1 examples/minimal.yaml

# OK: can sky stop + sky start + sky exec
git checkout master
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-2 examples/minimal.yaml
git checkout project-name
sky stop -y commit-4240-2
sky start -y commit-4240-2
sky exec commit-4240-2 examples/minimal.yaml

# OK: can `sky autostop` + `sky status -r`
git checkout master
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-3 examples/minimal.yaml
git checkout project-name
sky autostop -y -i0 commit-4240-3
sleep 100
sky status -r | grep commit-4240-3 | grep STOPPED
```

Back compat tests: old cluster, STOPPED: can be reused
```bash
# OK: (1 node) can sky launch + sky exec + sky queue + sky logs
git checkout master
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-4 examples/minimal.yaml
sky stop -y commit-4240-4
git checkout project-name
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-4 examples/minimal.yaml
sky queue commit-4240-4
sky logs commit-4240-4 1 --status
sky logs commit-4240-4 2 --status
sky logs commit-4240-4 1
sky logs commit-4240-4 2

# OK: (1 node) can sky start + sky exec + sky queue + sky logs
git checkout master
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-5 examples/minimal.yaml
sky stop -y commit-4240-5
git checkout project-name
sky start -y commit-4240-5
sky queue commit-4240-5
sky logs commit-4240-5 1 --status
sky logs commit-4240-5 1
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-5 examples/minimal.yaml
sky queue commit-4240-5
sky logs commit-4240-5 2 --status
sky logs commit-4240-5 2

# OK: (2 nodes) can sky launch + sky exec + sky queue + sky logs
git checkout master
sky launch -y -c commit-4240-6 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
sky stop -y commit-4240-6
git checkout project-name
sky start -y commit-4240-6
sky queue commit-4240-6
sky logs commit-4240-6 1 --status
sky logs commit-4240-6 1
sky exec commit-4240-6 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
sky queue commit-4240-6
sky logs commit-4240-6 2 --status
sky logs commit-4240-6 2
```

body:
This PR enables TPU Pod usage. To change from single TPU and TPU pod, user only needs to modify
`accelerators: tpu-v2-8` to `accelerators: tpu-v2-32`.

`sky launch` and `sky exec` will sync filemount/run setup/execute codes on all the TPU pod nodes.

Note: GCP does not support stopping a tpu pod [ref](https://cloud.google.com/tpu/docs/managing-tpus-tpu-vm#stopping_your_resources).

title: UX: print "this will block" hint right before blocking.
body:
```
# On a T4:1 instance.

# Wait till this job gets submitted.
sky exec sky-97c8-zongheng   'sleep 100' --gpus T4 

# Submitting another job, which will be blocked:
sky exec sky-97c8-zongheng   'sleep 100' --gpus T4
```
Now the output will look like
```
SKY INFO: Tip: use Ctrl-C to exit log streaming (task will not be killed).
SKY INFO: Waiting for task resources on 1 node. This will block if the cluster is full.

title: Add example for inference server
body:
This is a first pass at how a server executing computations on Sky might be implemented. The use case I have in mind is when a user wants to execute certain computations on Sky triggered by HTTP requests, and based on the request parameters as input.

To test it out:
1. Update the `LOCAL_UPLOAD_FOLDER` variable and data init file mount path.
2. `FLASK_APP=examples/inference_server/server.py flask run` then access `http://127.0.0.1:5000` and upload an image. The server spins up a Sky cluster, initializes the cluster with some model weights, runs some computation on the uploaded image, and returns the result as the HTTP response.

Some thoughts on the implementation:
- Currently, there does not seem to be a good way of retrieving the return value of a function. As such, I had to use regex and logs to extract the result of the function. This is not ideal, but I believe it is being addressed by #978
- Because the handler launches a new Sky cluster, the request is very long running, taking > 10 min currently. I have 2 ideas for how to improve this: 
  - Use a task queue like [Celery](https://docs.celeryq.dev/en/stable/) to execute the computations in the background when the handler is called, and return the job ID instead. User can use the job ID to poll the status of the job.
  - It looks like `sky.launch` takes the bulk of the time. If all the computations can be executed on the same cluster, we can have a setup function run before the first request is made that spins up the cluster, and subsequent computations will all be run on this cluster using `sky.exec`.

Let me know what you think!

title: `force_managed` field for Storage
body:
This PR introduces a new argument to sky storage - `force_managed`. If `force_managed` is set to True and the storage object points to an existing user owned bucket (e.g, `source=s3://my-existing-bucket`), the storage object `my-existing-bucket` will get populated in `sky storage ls`. 

This is required for #959, #974.


# Before
If I create a bucket through aws cli
```
aws s3 mb s3://my-external-bucket
```

And then run this YAML: 
```
file_mounts:
  /mymount:
    source: s3://my-external-bucket 
    mode: MOUNT
```

My `sky storage ls ` would have been empty.

```
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:~$ sky storage ls
No existing storage.
```
# After

If I set `force_managed: true`:
```
file_mounts:
  /mymount:
    source: s3://my-external-bucket 
    force_managed: true
    mode: MOUNT
```

My `sky storage ls`:
```
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:~$ sky storage ls
NAME                   CREATED    STORE  COMMAND                                 STATUS
romil-external-bucket  1 min ago  S3     sky launch -c force force_managed.yaml  READY
```


## Tested
- [ ] `./run_smoke_tests.sh`
- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials`

## TODO:
- [ ] Add support for force_managed for `gcs` (will be done in this PR)
- [ ] Update docs

title: Add host VM - GPU compatibility checks for GCP
body:
This PR checks compatibility between GCP host VMs and accelerators. For example, GPUs (except A100) can be only attached to N1 machines, and each GPU has limitations on the number of vCPUs and amount of CPU memory that its host VM can have. This PR hard-codes such information in `gcp_catalog.py` and lets users know when their requests are invalid.

* `sky gpunode --instance-type a2-highgpu-1g --gpus A100:2 -c test` (invalid)

title: Optimizing & Provisioning Retries at the granularity of regions/zones
body:
This PR closes #930 

For on-demand instances, the optimizer selects the **cloud region** (e.g., AWS us-west-1) to run the task on. And a provisioning request is made for that region. If it fails, Sky re-runs the optimizer and retries for the next cheapest cloud region (e.g., it can be GCP us-east1).

For spot instances, the optimizer additionally decides the **availability zone** (e.g., AWS us-west-1a). A provisioning request is made for that zone. If it fails, Sky re-runs the optimizer and retries for other zones (possibly in other clouds and regions).

This PR also fixes many bugs when a region is specified with `sky launch`. For example,

* `sky launch "" -c test --gpus V100 --cloud aws --region us-west-1`: us-west-1 does not have p3 instances. However, Sky does not return errors before launching.
* `sky launch "" -c test --gpus K80 --region southcentralus`: The price of Standard_NC6_Promo in the southcentralus region is $ 0.22 / hour, but the optimizer says it is $ 0.18/hour, which is the price of the instance in other regions.


Tests:
- [x] Smoke tests
- [x] `sky launch "" --use-spot --cloud aws --gpus A100:8`
- [x] `sky tpunode --region europe-west4` (NOTE: this command fails because our GCP catalog does not have any N1 machines for the regions outside the US.)
- [x] `sky tpunode --region europe-west4 --tpu-vm` (NOTE: this command succeeds because TPU VMs do not require N1 machines.)

title: [Demo] Sky local mode using onprem + docker
body:
# Sky local mode with onprem + docker

This PR is a demo to showcase the use of sky's upcoming onprem capabilities to deploy sky onto containers (and run sky locally on the user's laptop using docker). This enables users to iterate faster with sky for quick local testing and reduces costs and development time for sky contributors.

The APIs in this PR have not undergone design review and the code is not intended for review - this PR is purely for demo purposes.

# How it works

1. We publish a pre-configured docker image with a `sky` user and a `root` user. (`public.ecr.aws/a9w6z7w5/sky:local`)

2. The user deploys sky onprem onto this container using `sky admin deploy` (or optionally, the `sky local up` shorthand in this PR)

3. A `docker` cluster gets registered in user's sky status. They can now use it a regular sky cluster (e.g., `sky launch -c docker minimal.yaml`) 

4. To cleanup, run `sky local down` 

# Caveats
1. I had to change the onprem implementation to use `sudo -u` instead of `sudo su` because `su` uses the system python (`/usr/bin/python`) instead of the conda environment setup for the user. I believe this is because `sudo su <user> -c` does not source the `.bashrc`.
2. The sky local image is inherited from `continuumio/miniconda3:4.11.0`, which does not contain many packages by default. This creates a difference wrt the default AMIs which may have more packages pre-installed. Thus, the `setup` for sky tasks that run on the cloud may not necessarily work for this local mode, but any sky tasks that work on this local mode should work on the cloud.

# Screenshots

### Deploy sky local container with `sky local deploy`

title: Switch the backend functions back to single underscore
body:
As stated in the style guide proposed by zongheng, we may want to switch back to single underscore prefix for the backend functions.
> Prepending a double underscore (__ aka “dunder”) to an instance variable or method effectively makes the variable or method private to its class (using name mangling); we discourage its use as it impacts readability and testability, and isn’t really private. Prefer a single underscore.

title: Sky Storage Download Feature
body:
Add a Sky Storage Download Feature. Also fixes #932.

To download a folder from a bucket using Sky Storage, run:
```
from sky.data import storage, StoreType

storage_obj.add_store(StoreType.S3)
storage_obj.download('~/Downloads/hello')
```
(also works for GCS)

## Tests

title: Enable custom image for AWS and GCP
body:
Closes #683.

This PR enables the user to specify their own image when launching a cluster.
```
# test_ami.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  region: us-east-1
  image_id: ami-0f17aadac8db87c56
setup:
  echo "running setup"

run: |
  echo 'hello sky'
```
```
# test_ami_gcp.yaml
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  image_id: projects/ubuntu-os-pro-cloud/global/images/family/ubuntu-pro-1804-lts
setup:
  echo "running setup"

run: |
  echo 'hello sky'
```

The current implementation has some limitations:
1. It only supports AWS for now.
2. The user has to manually specify the cloud and region when the `image_id` is provided.
3. The image used for launching the instances may need to be debian-based, ~~and have pip3 installed.~~

TODOs:
- [x] Support GCP
- [x] Add doc

Future TODOs:
- Support Azure

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami test_ami.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami test_ami.yaml` again with a different AMI and it fails as expected for resource not match.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami-gcp test_ami_gcp.yaml`.
- [x] `sky launch -c nvidia-ami nvidia-ami.yaml`
  ```
  # nvidia-ami.yaml
  resources:
    cloud: aws
    region: us-east-1
    image_id: ami-0b0bae438f4bea93f
    accelerators: V100
  setup: |
    echo "running setup"
  
  run: |
    echo 'hello sky'
  ```
- [x] `./tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Enhance YAML schema validation
body:
Fixes #674.

Currently, the YAML schema validation only throws errors for unknown fields. It does not have support for required / optional fields, enum checks and type checks. 

I propose using the [JSON Schema](https://json-schema.org/) format to define and validate schemas for the YAML configuration file.  Although there are a number of mature Python libraries for data validation ([schema](https://github.com/keleshev/schema), [pydantic](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/), [ceberus](https://docs.python-cerberus.org/en/stable/) etc.), the main benefit of using JSON Schema is that it is an open specification and so we are not bound to any one implementation.

This PR replaces the current YAML validation with a validation based on JSON Schema that allows for handling unknown fields, enum checks, type checks and potentially a lot more complex validation as required. Similar to the current implementation, it also suggests the most similar field when an unknown field is encountered.

Tested:
- [Full configuration](https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/reference/yaml-spec.html)
- Failing enum checks (e.g. `cloud: gcs` instead of `cloud: gcp` )
- Failing type checks (e.g. `num_nodes: one` instead of `num_nodes: 1`)
- Unknown fields (e.g. `num_workers` instead of `num_nodes`)

From what I see from the docs, there are no required fields so the schema does not specify any.

title: Mount mode support for GCS
body:
This PR adds support for FUSE mounting GCS using gcsfuse. 

* Updated `examples/storage/pingpong.yaml` to use gcs.
* We need to update the optimizer to automatically pick the right backing store if `store` is not specified in the Storage YAML. That's a bigger effort (how do we pick which backing store to use? do we migrate if required?) and probably a separate PR.
* Functionally gcsfuse seems okay. At a cursory glance the performance seems comparable to goofys, but we need to formally benchmark this. gcsfuse also very likely suffers from similar [OOM issues](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gcsfuse/issues/679) as goofys.

Closes #915.

title: Refresh the cluster status with the cloud CLI
body:
Partially fixes #904.
This PR is the first step for using cloud CLI tools to fetch the cluster status. Although I implemented the status fetching for all the nodes in clusters, I am trying to be conservative in this PR, without letting the cluster status always up-to-date. Here are several reasons:
1. We do not want to set the cluster to UP, even if the CLI tells us all the nodes in the cluster are running, since the ray cluster may not be correctly set yet, i.e. the cluster should be in INIT status.
1. We need to deal with the status transition of the clusters, e.g. `sky launch` will transit the cluster status from `None` to `INIT` and then to `UP`, or `sky stop` will transit the cluster status from `UP` to `STOPPED`. If we update the status too frequently, there will be race conditions. For example:
  a. `sky launch` adds the INIT status in the DB, `ray up` has not started the instance yet.
  b. user call `sky status -r`: sky finds the cluster_name does not exist and removes the entry for that cluster from the database.
  c. `sky launch` is interrupted by the user, when the node is already launched, but not ready, so no new entries are written back to the database.
  d. Then there is a resource leakage since the cluster is removed from the database, but the node has been launched.
1. The case for multi-node clusters is very complicated, as we need to distinguish whether the cluster is partly terminated by the user manually through the UI, is auto-stopping, or is in the middle of launching.
1. For the spot cluster, we may want to set the spot cluster to STOPPED, to avoid confusing the user with why their cluster disappeared. Stopping after preemption is the default behavior for GCP and Azure, but AWS does not support stopping the spot instance when preemption happens (only supported when the spot request is persistent, i.e. keeps trying automatically after preempted).

Main changes:
1. Added functions for updating fetching the real cluster status using the cloud-specific CLIs.
1. Handle the edge case where the user manually stops or terminates the cluster in the cloud UI, as mentioned in #904.

Tested:
```
NAME                  LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                  STATUS   AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                             
test-fetch-state-gcp  10 hrs ago   2x GCP(n1-highmem-8)       UP       -         sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
test-fetch-state      9 hrs ago    2x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        UP       0 min     sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
sky-cpunode-zhwu      3 hrs ago    1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  -         sky cpunode                         
sky-e895-zhwu         10 mins ago  1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge[Spot])  UP       -         sky launch --use-spot --cloud aws  
```
Using `sky status -r` takes 7.3 sconds.
```
NAME                  LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                  STATUS   AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                             
test-fetch-state-gcp  10 hrs ago   2x GCP(n1-highmem-8)       UP       -         sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
test-fetch-state      9 hrs ago    2x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  0 min     sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
sky-cpunode-zhwu      3 hrs ago    1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  -         sky cpunode                         
sky-e895-zhwu         11 mins ago  1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge[Spot])  UP       -         sky launch --use-spot --cloud aws  
```

title: Revamp CLI docs/help messages.
body:
The CLI Ref doc page is highly viewed. This PR polishes it so it reads better.

Changes
- several backticks didn't render in html correctly as code; changed to double-backticks
- rewordings 
- reformatting

Tested:
- rendered the "CLI Reference" page locally
- check each `sky cmd --help`
